through the pandemic, highlighting the use of digital technology to help mitigate the impact of the lockdown on young peoplersquos mental health.

title: staff-face-redundancy-borders-call-centre--
story: STAFF are facing redundancy at a Galashiels call centre.Sykes has engaged its Nether Road employees in a consultation over their jobs.A Border reader, who said they work at the call centre, told us: "It cant be helped but its devastating to be losing work at a horrible time."A spokesperson for Sykes said: "After careful review we have started consultation about a reduction in the workforce at our Galashiels site."Staff were told about the job losses around three weeks ago, according to the employee who contacted the Border .The employee - who we have granted anonymity - said staff were informed their contracts are coming to an end, with managers also affected."I feel pretty stressed, everyone is feeling the pressure and are worried what to do," the source said.They added: "Theres added stress of finding a job at a time with hardly any jobs available."Some people may be lucky and walk into a new job."Im looking for employment, hoping theres something to take on or Im going to have to seek help from the Job Centre."The source also revealed that the redundancy talks are having an impact on the mental health of some staff."Ive spoken to others and theyre all struggling - their mood is very low, the source said, adding: "People with houses, kids or mortgages are going to struggle.A Sykes spokesperson said: "Sykes is responsive to the needs of the market and our clients in a constantly changing business landscape."The decision to make such changes is never easy."After careful review we have started consultation about a reduction in the workforce at our Galashiels site."The Border has contacted the company to ask how many jobs will be lost.Have you been affected by redundancy talks in the Borders  Get in touch by emailing: editorial@bordertelegraph

title: face-masks-scotland-two-key-mistakes-everyone-making
story: TODAY marks two weeks since face coverings became mandatory in shops across Scotland.So far, just one person has been handed a pound fine for not complying with the rules ndash as the country tries to further control the suppression of the coronavirus.The Scottish Government says that in enclosed spaces, where physical distancing is more dficult with people who are not members of your household, you should wear a face covering.By law, you must wear a covering in shops and on public transport ndash with similar rules coming into force in England today.But there are some parts of the guidance that many people seem to be forgetting.They are:When applying or removing the covering, it is important that you wash sanitise your handsfirst and avoid touching your face.After EACH USE, you must wash the face covering at  degrees centigrade or dispose of it safely.Who is exempt from wearing a covering Some people are not required to wear a face covering.These include:Children under fiveyears of age.Police constables or workers such as paramedics acting in the course of their duty.Staff such as drivers or checkout assistants who are physically separated, by means of, for example, screens, from passengers or customers.Shop workersthey maintain a two-metre distance from customers or members of the public.You are required by law to wear a face covering in Scotlands shops and on public transport .Find out how you can #StaySafeand protect others ##mdash Scottish GovernmentJuly , You may also have a reasonable excuse not to wear a face covering , for example:You have a health condition or you are disabled and a face covering would be inappropriate because it would cause dficulty, pain or severe distress or anxiety or because you cannot apply a covering and wear it in the proper manner safely and consistently.Inidual discretion should be applied in considering the use of face coverings for other children including, for example, children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who would struggle to wear a face covering.You need to eat or drink.You are taking medication.You are communicating with someone  who relies on lip reading.A relevant person, such as a police officer, asks you to remove your face covering.

title: 13-unusual-quirky-places-holiday-scotland
story: IF you are looking for a staycation that stokes the imagination, Scotland has no shortage of unusual and quirky gems.With the nationrsquos tourism sector now reopened, wersquove put together a list of some of our favourite awe-inspiring holiday accommodation.Places that bring together architectural wizardry and painstaking refurbishment to breathe new le ndash and use ndash into everything from a lighthouse to a modern-day broch and erstwhile modes of transportation, including buses, train carriages and even a helicopter.Roulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersThere is something wonderfully romantic about this circle of seven colourful roulotteslocated in a pretty wildflower meadow below the Eildon Hills.Each roulotte faces onto a lochan at the centre of the site. Facilities include sunset decks, wood-burning stoves, eco saunas and hot tubs. Itrsquos a perfect getaway for nature lovers with owls, deer, foxes, and badgers among the regular visitors.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit roulotteretreatHelicopter Glamping, Mains Farm Wigwams, Thornhill, StirlingStay in a Sea King helicopter complete with mini kitchen, bathroom and a cockpit seating area offering stunning views over the Forth Valley. The helicopter ndash part of Mains Farm Wigwams ndash sleeps two adults or a family of five . Therersquos a double bed, a single bed in the tail and seating which converts into a second double bed. The owners are currently renovating a  Scottish Aviation Twin Pioneer plane set to open for overnight stays next year.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit mainsfarmwigwamsSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandChoose between a vintage railway carriage, a freight wagon or the Waiting Room BB.Located beside a ing train station at Rogart , Sleeperzzz offers budget accommodation for backpackers, families, walkers, cyclists or those who simply fancy spending the night somewhere a bit dferent ndash such as a -ton goods van from the s.A great base for exploring Dunrobin Castle and the North Coast .Prices from poundpp per night. Call   or visit sleeperzzzCraighead Howfs, Dunblane, PerthshireBe transported to The Shire ndash which could be Perthshire or JRR Tolkienrsquos fictional Middle-earth in The Lord of the Rings, depending on how you look at it ndash with these magical Hobbit Howfs.The Burrow and Bagend are built into the hillside with grassy roofs and round doors for an unforgettable glamping experience. Craighead Howfs also offers the chance to stay in a treehouse with panoramic views over the Ochils and a secluded summer house.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit craigheadhowfThe Bus Stop, Gford, East LothianIf you have ever wanted to enjoy a Summer Holiday in the vein of the  film, look no further. This fleet of buses in a field belonging to an arable farm in East Lothian have been transformed into holiday accommodation with armchairs, sofas, lanterns, hot flasks, log stoves and beds.Each bus has a private wood-fired hot tub and barbecue fire pit. Choose from rustic or luxury ndash the latter have en suite bathrooms and swish mod cons. Oh, and therersquos gorgeous views of the Lammermuir Hills.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit thebusstop.scotBrockloch Eco Retreat, Kirkpatrick Durham, Castle DouglasFeatured on George Clarkersquos Amazing Spaces, Brockloch Eco Retreat is small but perfectly formed. Located on a working farm, therersquos two units: a contemporary, off-grid, micro-timber bothy facing into an open field and an incredible treehouse hideaway within a bluebell wood where the closest neighbours are red squirrels.The treehouse has a built-in double bed with a skylight to gaze at the treetops and stars as you drt off to sleep. This part of the world is a great place to see red kites.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit brocklochBlack Isle Yurts, Eathie Hill, RosemarkieSet in private woodland, all of the yurts within this eco-sensitive, wild-glamping site are based on designs used by nomadic people in Central Asia for thousands of years.In keeping with the Scottish climate, the traditional felt outer shell has been replaced with a waterproof canvas and therersquos a wood-burning stove to stay cosy on cooler nights. The site is a short drive from Chanonry Point which is fantastic for dolphin spotting.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit blackisleyurtsRua Reidh Lighthouse, near Gairloch, Wester RossBuilt in  by David Alan Stevenson, a cousin of the writer Robert Louis Stevenson and one of the famous ldquoLighthouse Stevensons, this beautul, remote location offers BB and self-catering, the latter in the charmingly named First Officerrsquos Quarters.Endless views, a glorious stretch of coastline, abundant bird and sea le, tranquillity, solitude and the thrill of potentially catching a glimpse of the Aurora Borealis on dark, starry nights awaits.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit stayatalighthouseCalgary, MullNot to be confused with the skyscraper-filled city in Alberta, this little corner of Mull is a delight.A byre, hayloft and dovecote are among the self-catering properties available at Calgary, each with its own distinctive character. Calgary also has an excellent cafe, art gallery and a woodland sculpture walk.Therersquos a beach within strolling distance where Robinrsquos Boat sells Isle of Mull ice cream. Sea eagles, otters and basking sharks can all be seen nearby.,params: .pushPrices start from pound for a seven-night stay. Call   or visit calgaryThe Scriptorium Apartments at St Benedictrsquos Abbey, Fort AugustusThe Scriptorium ndash the once secret writing room of the monastery ndash has two one-bedroom apartments with vaulted ceilings, gothic archways and stained-glass windows. Therersquos plenty to do in the grounds and gardens, be it tennis, badminton, croquet or giant chess. The former Monksrsquo Refectory has been converted into a Club Lounge and a chapel refurbished to incorporate a heated pool, sauna and steam room.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit parrandierThe Brochs of Coigach, near Achiltibuie, UllapoolBrochs are an ancient dwelling found only in Scotland, dating back to BC. Gille Buidhersquos Broch and Scalrsquos Broch are a bit younger than thatand beautully enchanting structures.If you love upcycling, they will impress, built using stones from old, crumbling walls on nearby land and timber recovered from a dilapidated Victorian pier. Oil paintings by John Bellany hang on the walls, alongside display cabinets filled with weird and wonderful objects.Prices from pound per night. Call   or visit thebrochsThe Four Sisters Boatel, EdinburghTucked away in the heart of the Scottish capital, this houseboat is permanently moored at the Lochrin Basin on the Union Canal ndash the eastern terminus for the -mile stretch of water that comes all the way from Falkirk. Sleeping up to six adults and two children, it is an ideal base to explore Edinburgh, with Bruntsfield and the West End, as well as the Old and New Towns, all just a stonersquos throw away.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit thefoursistersThe Sawmill at Glen Dye, Banchory, AberdeenshireTalk about enjoying the great outdoors in style. Stay in a sleek, refurbished s Airstream Safari caravan in a small pine wood beside the fast flowing lade of a sawmill.A rustic, wooden seed store with roots back to the s serves as the kitchen, dining and sitting room. There are games, books, a record player and a memorable barbecue spot. Glen Dye also offers a river cabin, a bothy and two steading cottages, as well as running residential courses in crafts and wild food.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit glendyecabinsandcottages

title: author-chris-lloyd-were-surrounded-magic
story: CHILDRENrsquoS author Chris Lloyd says lockdown makes it feel like ldquosomeone has switched the gravity off.The Kent-based non-fiction writer spoke to the Border ahead of his turn at the virtual version of the Borders Book Festival, the physical event having been cancelled due to coronavirus.When not grappling with zero-gravity, Lloyd, , has spent the last  years writing books for children, inspired by nature and the history of the world beyond humans.Discussing his  release, Humanimal, Lloyd said: "Children are born with an instinct, an intuition that all living things are connected and that theyre part of an ecosystem."This is the way we are naturally but society and culture tend to beat that out of us ndash they tell us were more intelligent."The point of the book is to try to preserve, for children, this reality of interconnectivity, and to give them some protection to whats happened to us adults over the years.ldquoWhich is the inevitable feeling that we are what matters and that everything  is there to serve us or for us to use or exploit."We cant continue with that mindset as a species and survive."As this is the message he is keen to share, Humanimaland Lloyds other works are not designed to act as an "A to Z encyclopaedia" of information, but rather tell the planets natural history away from the impact of humanity."All my books are meant for adults as well as children," said Lloyd. ldquoTheyre illustrated and designed in a way that makes adults want to buy them for children and I hope children want to share them with adults."Its a book, its a story, its something to be discussed, its something to be read out loud, its something to be looked at together.ldquoIts not a book and a child, its really something to open doors as much as anything ."And Lloyd believes, as much magic as there is in fiction, non-fiction ndash and the content that inspires it ndash can hold just as much whimsy.He said: "For me non-fiction has always been the more magical part of literature. There are a lot of young people for whom the real world is more amazing than anything you could make up."Again, thats another thing were born with that gets beaten out of us, and we start using the word ordinary ndash and theres nothing ordinary."Were surrounded by magic. You think Harry Potters magic  Just look around you."That curiosity is our biggest asset because thats how we learn to adapt, thats how we learn to survive, thats how we learn to cope with the world around us as it changes."Lloyd, who previously worked as a Sunday Timesjournalist, was inspired to begin a career as a childrens author after seeing the joy his children experienced when they learnt new things during their years in home-schooling.Particularly that of one of his daughters who was astonished to learn all about Antarctica ndash home of her then favourite animal, the penguin."I believe fundamentally, especially now having done thousands of talks in schools and festivals over the last  years, that humans generally reach peak curiosity at the age of nine or ," Lloyd said."Then things start to get in the way, like puberty and your friendship groups change and going from primary to secondary school."But at the age of nine or  youve got that purity of curiosity where youre old enough to know that you have an identity and youre curious enough to want to know where you fit in."Theres nothing you cant talk to a nine or -year-old about ndash provided you dont patronise them, provided you dont have an expectation of them that they cant meet."If you can meet them as fellow kindred spirits on this rock travelling around the sun, in this incredible galaxy, and here we are, face to face, learning about it and discovering things together, then there is nothing more inspiring than engaging with a nine or -year-old."Chris Lloyds Humanimalbook event will be broadcast on Sunday, July  at am as part of the festivals Family Series, and will include a discussion portion after a short presentation by Lloyd.The event is suitable for families with children aged seven and over.

title: sykes-redundancies-john-lamont-seeks-meeting-bosses
story: BORDERS MP John Lamont is seeking an ldquourgent meeting with call centre bosses following news of redundancies in Galashiels.Sykes employees face losing their jobs at Nether Road.Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, described the looming redundancies as ldquodevastating.He said: ldquoThis is an already very uncertain and stressful time for many people so it will be particularly dficult for those workers affected.A Sykes spokespersontold the Border on July  that staff are being consulted about job losses.But some employees later approached this newspaper to say every worker has been told their last day will be at the end of August, when the entire call centre will close.Sykes has been contacted for further comment.Mr Lamont said: ldquoThe reports of these redundancies at the Sykes call centre is devastating.ldquoThis is an already very uncertain and stressful time for many people so it will be particularly dficult for those workers affected.ldquoSykes are a big employer in the Borders so these job losses will add further challenges for our local economy as it begins to recover from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoI am seeking an urgent meeting with the management team to see what support can be provided.ldquoFor anybody who is worried about their job and is looking for advice, I would encourage them to contact me and I will do my best to assist.

title: borders-book-festival-2020-line-up-august-announced
story: DAVID Baldacci, Sara Pascoe and Sebastian Barry are among the stars appearing at the online Borders Book Festival in August.The online edition of the festival, which launched on July , offers free-to-view talks every week.The line-up for August has now been unveiled, with festival director Alistair Moffat hailing a ldquodynamic schedule.Mr Moffat said: ldquoWersquove been delighted with the positive response wersquove received since the virtual festival launched this month and are excited to reveal a lively and eclectic line-up for August.Former Love Islandcontestant Camilla Thurlow is among the guests due to appear.Others include crime writer Val McDermid, broadcaster Sally Magnusson and childrenrsquos author Alan Windram ndash who is from Galashiels.This is the full line-up for AugustSunday, August am: Alan Windram will be launching the latest title from his award-winning picture book series One Button Bennypm: Broadcaster and novelist Sally Magnusson on myth, immortality and the role of women in society with festival director Alistair Moffatpm: US bestselling thriller writer David Baldacci talks to Lee Randall about his latest novel A Minute to MidnightSunday, August am: Hilarious adventures from Wigglesbottom Primary with Pamela Butchartpm: Dutch historian Rutger Bregman presents a new view on human naturepm: Award-winning novelist Sebastian Barry on his latest novel A Thousand MoonsSunday, August am: Eilidh Muldoon will show young viewers how to draw a very sleepy owl in this launch event for Snooze.pm: Environmental campaigner Jonathon Porritt presents a compelling blueprint for post-COVID - recoverypm: Former Bishop of Edinburgh, and bestselling author Richard Holloway helping us to make sense of the world with writer and broadcaster Sally MagnussonThursday, August pm: The riotously funny comedian Sara Pascoe will be joining the festival with an exclusive midweek special event on modern masculinity and sexual economicsSunday rd Augustam: Fun facts and drawing tips from master cartoonist Gary Northfield, the creator of the hilarious Julius Zebra bookspm: How to change the world with young activist and entrepreneur Jeremiah Emmanuelpm: Unrivalled queen of crime Val McDermid on her latest heart-pounding thriller Still LeSunday, August am: Much-loved Sir Charlie Stinky Socks author, Kristina Stephensonpm: Reflections on celebrity culture and mental health with Camilla Thurlow and her inspirational new memoir Not The Typepm: Dr Amir Khan, from Channel rsquos Behind Closed Doors, talks about his brand-new book The Doctor Will See You Now and tells us how he helped lead one of the busiest GP surgeries in the country through the unprecedented trials of the COVID pandemic.All events from the July programme are still available to view for free at any time from the festival website www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: borders-football-fans-tell-stories-new-book
story: FOOTBALL fans from Galashiels are featured in new book examining rivalries from around the world.Us and Them: New Journeys in Football Rivalry is published by anti-sectarian charity Nil By Mouth.As well as including accounts from Bilbao, China and Kosovo, the book tells the stories of Tam Cass and Johnny Sweeney, who watched their teams compete in the tragic Ibrox Stadium Disaster fixture of  where  fans lost their lives.The chapter lsquoCity Rivalsrsquo was written by Nil by Mouth director Dave Scott, who lives in the Borders.He said: ldquoFootball rivalry, especially when it comes to the lsquoOld Firmrsquo, is a cocktail of pride, passion, pantomime and poison.ldquoIt would be easy to focus on the negatives but we choose to look at some interesting stories of friendship across the ide, both on and off the pitch, examining the relationship between [Celticrsquos] Billy McNeill and [Rangers player] John Greig as well as allowing supporters the opportunity to tell their own stories.ldquoTam and Johnnyrsquos story is an extremely powerful one as it shows how they could easily set aside sporting rivalry when faced which much deeper human experiences.Writers who have contributed to the book include Daniel Gray and Andrew Downie.Visit nilbymouth.org for more information.

title: border
story: AN MSP is calling for Borderers to be mindful of those who cannot wear face coverings for medical reasons.The masks became mandatory in shops and on public transport several weeks ago.But there are exemptions, such as people with a health condition or living with a disability.And Borders MSP Rachael Hamilton is encouraging retailers, shopkeepers and the general public to be considerate and to adhere to the two-metre social distancing rule when near people without a covering.She said: ldquoWe need to all look out for each other at this dficult time.ldquoWearing face coverings in shops reduces the risk of transmission but we must be mindful that not everyone can wear one.ldquoSome people with medical conditions or disabilities are unable to wear face coverings, and we must recognise that they will require more personal space when moving around shops.ldquoThat is why, regardless of face coverings, to remain at a safe distance from people in shops and enclosed spaces."The British Lung Foundation has produced a downloadable graphic that people can show on their phones to explain why they arenrsquot wearing a face covering.The card aims to inform staff when entering shops and supermarkets, and on public transport.Sarah MacFadyen, head of policy at Asthma UK and the British Lung Foundation, said: ldquoItrsquos important to wear a face covering where advised not only to protect yourself but others around you, who could be more vulnerable to COVID-."However, we need a greater awareness that there are exemptions from the rules on face coverings, and this includes people with severe respiratory conditions."Most people will be able to wear a face covering with no problem, but some people find that wearing a mask makes them feel like they canrsquot breathe.Visit www.blf.org.uk to download the graphic.

title: msps-call-signs-display-virus-advice-cross-border-routes
story: THREE MSPs have written to transport bosses in a bid to get the latest COVID- advice displayed on electronic road signs in the Borders.Last week, Christine Grahame and fellow SNP politicians Emma Harper and Joan McAlpine sent as joint letter to the chief executives of Transport Scotland and Highways England.They want the information boards on cross-border routes to highlight the dferences in coronavirus restrictions.The MSPs said some of their constituents were "concerned" that visitors coming into the region from other parts of the UK were unfamiliar with the dferences in the COVID- rules.And that the confusion had even caused "animosity" with local businesses and residents.Christine Grahame, MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, said: "While I welcome people coming to visit the Borders ndash world-renowned for its history and outstanding scenery ndash we want to ensure that people enjoy the area safely and understand that in Scotland we have our own approach to easing the COVID- restrictions, which dfers from the approach taken by other parts of the UK."To this end, we have jointly written to the chief executives of Transport Scotland and Highways England to request that electronic road signage on cross-border routes between the two nations reflect the dferences in COVID- restrictions.ldquoScotland has made excellent progress towards stopping the spread of COVID-, and now as we are starting to see more of our tourism, leisure and hospitality businesses open, we want to ensure this good progress continues while keeping local communities safe.ldquoOne way to inform people is by ensuring that everyone is aware of the measures which are in place in Scotland, as they head north, and England as they head south, which we encourage everyone to follow.ldquoWe look forward to hearing back from both Transport Scotland and Highways England soon.

title: double-decker-bus-cafe-set-park-prestonpans
story: The proposals have been given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council, with the bus to be sited at the eastern end of Prestonpans, off the B.Matsform Ltd, the company behind the plans, told the local authority that the vehicle could be in a colour ldquosympathetically chosen to complement the coastal character of the site.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe applicant has submitted a supporting statement that details how the proposed cafe would operate.ldquoIt advises that the proposed cafe would operate within the double-decker bus which is proposed to be sited within the John Muir Way car park for locals and visitors to enjoy.ldquoIt is indicated that the ground floor of the bus would contain a kitchen and one accessible table, with the upper floor of the bus used as a seating area with some  tables and four additional seats.ldquoThe agent indicates that the cafe would operate seasonally from am to pm Tuesday through Sunday from April to September, and from am to pm Wednesday through Sunday from October to March.ldquoThe bus will be positioned on the site at all times and would not be removed when not open for business.The proposals did not attract any comment from the townrsquos community council.One objection from the public focused on the potential of litter and waste from the proposed cafe.However, it was highlighted that matters relating to waste were not ldquomaterial considerations when it came to determining a planning application and would be tackled through other legislation.Planning permission has been given for one year to allow the council to ldquoassess the environmental impact of the development, while a planning condition stating that bins should be provided outside the bus at all times while trading has also been included.

title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have identied a possible start for the new campaign.The Lowland East South West Pyramid group ndash representing teams from the Scottish Lowland Football League, the East of Scotland Football League, the South of Scotland Football League and the West of Scotland Football League ndash held its first Zoom call earlier this month.Clubs are hoping to restart training in the coming weeks, with a view to playing again at the end of September or beginning of October.Managers from East Lothianrsquos teams cautiously welcomed the announcement and hoped it was the start of light at the end of the tunnel.Geoff Jones, manager of Dunbar United, said: ldquoI think, to be honest, it is an enormous boost.ldquoNot just from a football perspective but just a mental health perspective as well ndash for a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having been appointed in February.The Foresters Park side will be looking to build on a promising campaign, which saw them sitting fourth in the East of Scotland Football League Premier Division when the season was stopped.Harvey said: ldquoTo get some kind of normality back in everybodyrsquos lives would be a huge boost.ldquoSupporters, players, myself ndash everybody is exactly the same and is excited to get back on the field as soon as possible.Kevin McDonald, manager at Musselburgh Athletic, was frustrated to see football halted in the spring with his side on an impressive run of form, including securing a place in this seasonrsquos Scottish Cup after a - thumping of Mid Annandale in the South and East Shield.Now, he is hoping to see that continue when the upcoming campaign gets under way.He said: ldquoI have been pestering the secretary at Musselburgh to find outhe has any information.ldquoWe are all desperate to get back ndash myself and the players are the same.ldquoWe will be looking at a seven-month break by the time we restart games.ldquoThe sooner we are allowed to get back training and playing friendlies the better.ldquoI think we will need more friendlies with not playing for so long as well.Joe Hamill, player-manager at Haddington Athletic, said everyone at the club was keen to see the season get back under way.He stressed that training could look slightly dferent than it did previously, with stringent cleaning measures being put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.He said: ldquoItrsquos a wee bit of light at the end of the tunnel for us. Irsquove been getting messages from the players asking lsquowhen are we starting back rsquoldquoIrsquom in the same boat and just want to get on with it.

title: plans-revealed-knock-bank-hall-former-rbs
story: The former Royal Bank of Scotland hall in North Berwick has been at the centre of a bid by new owners to create a home on the site since it was closed two years ago and sold by the financial institute.However, the hall is an extension to a Category B-listed building which would have been the bank managerrsquos home at one point, and listed building consent was needed to change it, as well as planning permission.Both were refused by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, leading to an appeal to Scottish Ministers and the local authorityrsquos Local Review Body.The Scottish Government Reporter ruled that, despite the claims of the agents for the owners that the extension itself was not an integral part of the Category B listed building, and had been added in the s, changes would impact on the Victorian building.Ruling in January, the Reporter said he believed theplanned changes would not only affect the historic interest of the listed building but would adversely affect the setting of the adjacent listed building and be ldquodetrimental to the character and appearance of the conservation area.The original plans for the conversion included a wine cellar and rumpus room as part of the new residence.However, planning officers told East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Review Body that the property was for commercial use and should remain so.They said that the council had received  letters of objection and seven in support of the plans, although they added that five of the supporting letters came from people who did not live in the town and they dismissed suggestions the new owners had ldquorobustly marketed the property for its intended purpose before applying to build the house.The new application proposes demolishing the bank hall, which had been described by some councillors at the Local Review Body meeting in November as ldquounattractive as they refused the original plans.It also proposes to set aside part of the ground floor of the new two-storey home for commercial purposes.In an application to the planning authority, the applicants say that the new home would include  square metres of space for ldquoflexible pop-up commercial business space to be rented short term to inidualsor companies requiring to use it.The plans are now on the council website for comment.

title: community-praised-racing-returns-musselburgh-racecourse
story: Musselburgh Racecourse saw racing resume behind closed doors at two events at the start of the month and held a third event recently.The move involved introducing security measures around the course, which is on Common Good land, to protect the public, racecourse staff and visitingjockeys.The land on which the racecourse operates is a popular walking spot for locals and dog walkers,with neighbouring lagoons.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said the course had received huge support from local residents as it sought to ensure fixtures could be held safely and meet health and safety standards.Ahead of the inaugural meeting, the racecourse put in place a lsquoGreen Zonersquo which ensured admission to the grounds was controlled and monitored to minimise the risk posed by Covid-.Safety barriers were erected at points around the course on Linkfield Road and stewards advised local residents where to access the course without encroaching on the Green Zone.Other measures included all attendees completing a compulsory Covid- education module, an online health questionnaire, providing personal details and photo ID, and on arrival undergoing temperature checks by qualied medical staff.Mr Farnsworth said the protocols had been agreed in advance with East Lothian Councilrsquos Safety Advisory Groupand the British Horseracing Authority in order to meet safety guidelines introduced by the Scottish Government.He said: ldquoWe understand the new procedures may have caused some inconvenience to local residents and we will refine the process when Covid- regulations are relaxed.ldquoWe do appreciate the continued support of the local community in bringing racing back to Musselburgh.ldquoThe purpose of the controlled measures is to ensure the safety of the participants on each race day and the safety of the local community, and we are acting on feedback received from local residents following the first two meetings.ldquoWe have placed additional signage on Linkfield Road to ensure the public who use the links and lagoons for recreation and dog walking are fully aware of the access areas during future race days.ldquoOur aim is to provide as much public access to the grounds surrounding the racecourse as possible, whilst operating a safe sporting event.

title: runner-makes-record-time-john-muir-way
story: James Stewart pulled on his running shoes on Friday, July , in Helensburgh and ran through the day and night to reach the finishing line on Dunbar High Street the next morning!The -mile route was opened in  by then First Minister Alex Salmond.On July , the five-mile limit for leisure travel was lted and James, from Croy in North Lanarkshire, set off for the start line.Leaving at am, he powered through torrential rain, which meant changes of footwear, to reach Dunbar at .am on Saturday.James was pleased to complete the route in  hours and  minutes and told the Courier he had been confident in completing it under  hours.He said: ldquoAt the end of the day, there are a couple of reasons why I was confident I could set the fastest known time.ldquoI know the guy who did it previously and I ran with him for a bit. He knew I was going to go for it and I was always confident I could do it under  hours because my  hoursrsquo personal best is  miles on a running track.ldquoThere is still a lot that can go wrong and you have got to keep moving. You never know when you are going to feel ill or turn an ankle and need to walk  miles, which can slow you down for an hour or two.The -year-old was aware of the route, which passes through Croy, before taking on the challenge.However, he did not do any ldquorecce on any of the  sections of the -kilometre route that he was unfamiliar with.Instead, armed with a head torch, he ran through the night to reach Dunbar.And, although the weather was wet in the west, he was rewarded for his efforts as he came into East Lothian.James, who works for Sky, said: ldquoWe had a stunning sunset going through Edinburgh.ldquoAs I came off Corstorphine Hill, I was dropping down into Brunstane and Musselburgh and at that point I was getting a really stunning sunset and knew I was going to get a great sunrise.ldquoIt was maybe dark for five hours and the sunrise as I came through the coast was incredible. The best bit of it was the sunrise over North Berwick Law.James was greeted by a welcoming party on Dunbar High Street shortly before am.Duncan Smeed, chair of John Muir Birthplace Charitable Trust, was on hand to present an IOU for a certicate to show he had completed the route.He said: ldquoI wanted to make sure somebody from the Birthplace was there to welcome him, even though we cannot open the Birthplace just yet.

title: special-tv-appearance-family-tiktok-marathon
story: Eight-year-old Mary Kidd, mum Karen, dad Gordon and older sister Abbie, , appeared on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best on Sunday, July , the pairrsquos chat show style programme.They appeared on the show, presented by father-and-son duo Martin and Roman Kemp, thanks to Maryrsquos six-hour TikTok dance marathon, which she completed on VE Day in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.Karen, a board member at the foundation, said: ldquoI got a message on Facebook from a producer at Cactus TV [an independent TV production company which owns runs the show], they were looking for inspirational families for the show.ldquoI was a wee bit unsure at first but the girl we spoke to was nice.ldquoThey saw Maryrsquos story online, I think it was the Courier online, and askedthey could give us a phone call.ldquoSo we had a couple of phone calls with them and they found out what happened and about the charity etc, like a pre-interview.ldquoRoman is also a big TikTok fan so he was really interested.The show was filmed on June  and took about one hour and  minutes in total to record. It was broadcast on STV ITV at .am last Sunday morning, July .As well as chats with actor and Spandau Ballet member Martin Kemp and his radio DJ and Irsquom a Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here! star son Roman, the family played some games and spoke to the showrsquos three guests Laura Whitmore, Beverly Knight and Jessie Ware.Karen said: ldquoWe just had normal chats with them, they made us feel very, very welcome. The whole experience was really good. They had some great chats with Mary.ldquoMartin and Roman were so nice and made us feel very at ease.ldquoI was more of a Duran Duran fan but I didnrsquot tell him that!ldquoItrsquos nice that they are recognising kids that have done something that wee bit dferent.ldquoIt was also nice to see what it takes to film a TV show and how it is all done ndash Roman fluffed his lines a couple of times. It was an honour and a privilege to have had the opportunity from ITV.Ahead of watching the show, Karen admitted she was nervous.However, afterwards she described it as ldquoone of the most surreal experiences and said she was really pleased with how the show turned out.She said that both Mary and Abbie also loved filming the show.She added a thanks to Mary for doing her TikTok challenge, which raised more than pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.

title: five-year-old-poppys-helping-hand-east-lothian-foodbank
story: Poppy Fulton was inspired to help East Lothian Foodbank after hearing her mum and dad, Ashley and Richard, talking about food parcels.The conversation spurred Poppy into walking with her mum from her home in Athelstaneford to Haddington at the end of last month ndash just days after she turned five.Her proud mum was delighted to say that the fundraiser had collected more than pound, for the Tranent-based good cause.She said: ldquoThe whole way round the walk, she was raring to go.ldquoI was expecting a little bit of resistance and to coax her at some points.ldquoShe got to the end and started to cry when she saw everybody cheering for her.ldquoShe is quite excited to go in and visit the foodbank.ldquoI cannot quite believe how many people have donated.As well as financial donations, supermarket giant Morrisons also got involved and donated several bags of food, which have also gone to the foodbank.Before the walk, Ashley, who works as a teacher at Royal High School in Edinburgh, and her husband, who works with City of Edinburgh Council in homeless prevention for young people, were talking about food parcels being delivered to people in need.Ashley said: ldquoPoppy asked why they would need to do that and we were explaining some people did not have food.ldquoShe was getting really upset and asking why and she could not understand why some people did not have food.ldquoShe was getting more upset and she said that we had to help them.ldquoWe set a target of pound and Poppy wanted to do a bake sale but we said we could not really do that just now.ldquoWe told her some people did a sponsored walk and she said: lsquoWe will do that.rsquoldquoShe hates walking so that was quite a big thing to do.ldquoShe drew her own wee poster with a picture of me and her walking and some food around it and started telling everybody she was going to do it.Originally, mum and daughter were planning to cover the -kilometre distance on Monday, June .However, torrential rain saw the walk pushed back  hours, with Ashley and Poppy setting off shortly after am the following day.Grandparents came out to show their support as the little fundraiser made her way towards Haddingtonrsquos Market Street and the finish line.Ashley also revealed her daughterrsquos enthusiasm for the challenge was such that they had to stop off on the townrsquos Riverside Drive ndash where she did cartwheels ndash to ensure the welcoming party were in place in the town centre.To support the youngster, go to www.justgiving fundraising Poppy-Fulton

title: yummikeys-enjoy-tasty-profit-lockdown
story: Elspeth Fawcett, who lives in Aberlady, founded Yummikeys, a company that produces stainless steel sensory toys for babies, in .Since lockdown began in March, monthly sales of her toys have trebled.The mum-of-three said: ldquoMy business is fairly well established online, and, although the nationrsquos spending on the whole has probably decreased over the past few months, people are spending more time online, babies are still being born, mothers are still breast feeding and teething is simply part of le.ldquoAs more millennials become parents, I thinktrendstowards increasing eco-awareness and companies seen to be vocallyin-line with this will do well.She added: ldquoHaving already sold over , this year and with plans to get to , by the end of , we are excited at the prospect of freeing up ,kg of single-use plastic.For more information, visit yummikeys

title: dementia-friendly-walks-win-accreditation-project
story: Ageing Well, run by East Lothian Council in partnership with NHS Lothian, has been organising walks in Dunbar for dementia sufferers during the past year in a bid to reach the benchmark set by Scotlandrsquos walking charity Paths for All.Parvine Jazayeri, Ageing Well coordinator, undertook the necessary training and, in turn, was able to train volunteer leaders to lead the dementia-friendly walks, which took place on Fridays prior to the Covid- pandemic.She consulted with DF groups and worked closely with new partners such as Alzheimer Scotland.A portfolio showcasing the initiative was created and sent to Paths for All, which awarded Ageing Well the accreditation for Dementia FriendlyWalking, which could be rolled out across East Lothian subject to volunteer training.Parvine, who is based at Meadowmill Sports Centre, near Tranent, said: ldquoOver the past year, Ageing Well has been working very hard on the new project. We already run  health walks in East Lothian.ldquoTo make our walks even more inclusive, we wanted to ensure everyone and anyone could access them.ldquoWe have now been awarded our accreditation. This is such a great achievement for the Ageing Well project.She added: ldquoThe accreditation is a way of recognising the work of the Walking for Health projects that have made changes to support people, who are living well in the community with dementia, to engage in walking. The DF project team at Paths For All gave guidance and support to me throughout the year. The walks can now be classed as DF and will be continuing once this crisis has passed.ldquoI just want to say a massive thank you to everyone who has supported this project, especially the walk leaders. We could not have done this without them.ldquoIt has been a busy year but the hard work has paid off.ldquoAlthough our health walks may not be operating at the moment, I hope people are able to find some time to enjoy a walk close to home.Parvine said it was also hoped to introduce health walks for East Lothian residents with cancer as part of the Macmillan Move More Scotland programme after the Covid- crisis.She has also been working in partnership with CHANGES, a Musselburgh-based community health project, as the two organisations run similar walking programmes.They are hoping to launch dementia-friendly buddy walks across the county in the future. These would offer people who donrsquot like the thought of walking in a big group another option.

title: 5-000-raised-annual-christian-aid-collection
story: Christian Aid Week, which took place in May, saw Haddingtonrsquos churches coming together in a bid to raise money for the global charity.However, where usually that would mean door-to-door collections, the collectors were faced with a new challenge as coronavirus restrictions saw the campaign move online.John Weierter, from Haddingtonrsquos Christian Aid group, said: ldquoNationally Christian Aid built an interactive site with streamed worship and ious other activities.ldquoLocally we set up a JustGiving page for the Haddington churches and made arrangements to receive cheques posted directly to Janet Chrystal of St Maryrsquos, or to Graham Coe of the West Church.ldquoWe then had to wait with bated breath for our faithful supporters to come to us instead of us going out to them."We neednrsquot have worried ndash pound, in cheques cash was sent to our local collectors, pound, was raised via our JustGiving page and we received an incredibly generous cheque for pound, from the Church of Christ in Haddington, who had sold their buildings and were dispersing their funds."They requested the money be used lsquoto help the poor and preach the Gospelrsquo and this is surely what will happen.That took the total to pound,.The grouprsquos JustGiving page remains open until tomorrowand can be accessed via justgiving fundraising haddingtonchurchescagroup

title: margiotta-looking-expand-across-east-lothian
story: Applying for a change of name for the former Londis Aberlady Village Store and opening hours, an agent for the new owners revealed it was just the first of a number of new ventures planned for the county.Alistair Macdonald, representing JELCM Ltd, which took over the store, said that while the company name might be unfamiliar to East Lothian Licensing Board members, the new shop name would not be.He said: ldquoJELCM is a new company set up by the Margiotta family who are a well-known retail family in Edinburgh. The company name is, I believe, made up of the initials of the grandchildren as this is seen as a venture for future generations. This is their first venture out of Edinburgh and it is hoped it will be the first of several properties in East Lothian.The Margiotta family took over the village shop in April but had been operating under old licensing conditions.The application asked for permission to formally change the shop name, extend its opening hours from pm to pm at night, add hot food and coffee takeaway services and deliveries.The board was told that the previous owner had closed at pm every evening not because it was a condition of licensing but because he was ldquoa family man.Two objections were lodged from members of the public concerned about the later opening hours and noise however, it was argued issues raised could be dealt with by staff.Councillor Jane Henderson, board member, welcomed the arrival of Margiotta in the county.She said: ldquoI find it very exciting and welcome Margiotta coming to East Lothian and the investment they are making. I wish them well.The application was approved unanimously.

title: comet-neowise-once-in-6800-years-chance-see-rare-comet-scotland-tonight
story: The mountain-sized Neowise comet made its closest approach to the sun on July  and is now shining brightly in the night skies.Neowise survived a close encounter with the sun, and during its closest approach will be about  million miles away from the earth ndash but still visible to the human eye.Comet Neowise is visible to the naked eyeDr Robert Massey, from the Royal Astrological Society, said Neowise was last in the inner Solar System  years ago and it was not expected tofor another  years.He said: ldquoI would encourage everyone to take a lookthey can,they have clear skies, and get away from light pollutionthey can.How and when can I see the comet Comet Neowise reaches its closest point to the earth tomorrow morning around  minutes before sunrise - at around .am.One easy way to spot the comet is to look for the Big Dipper- which should be visible eastwards on a clear night with little light pollution.Neowise should be below the Big Dipper, about  degrees above the horizon.What has NASA said A Nasa spokesman said: ldquoA comet has suddenly become visible to the unaided eye.ldquoComet C  Fwas discovered in late March and brightened as it reached its closest approach to the sun, inside the orbit of Mercury, late last week.ldquoThe interplanetary iceberg survived solar heating, so far, and is now becoming closer to the Earth as it starts its long trek back to the outer Solar System."NASA also provided their own three tips to seeing Neowise:

title: mum-says-i-literally-begging-people-save-life
story: Trudie Murphy is hoping to fly out to the USA for treatment which could see the tumour removed.She was given the horrible news last week that specialists in Scotland would be unable to remove the cancerous tumour, while chemotherapy was also not an option.Doctors have said that she could receive radiotherapy but it would be as a last resort to extend her le.Now, a close friend, Colin Rillie-Caldwell, has launched an online appeal looking to raise more than pound,, which would be used to cover the cost of treatment.Trudie, who works part-time in Tranentrsquos Asda store, admitted to the Courier she was ldquopessimistic but would love the money to be raised to give her extra time with her children.She said: ldquoI would love to see it happen, to be able to be around for my kids ndash that is my sole driving force.ldquoThis GoFundMe page, I feel embarrassed because I feel like it is begging but I thought: lsquoI am literally begging for people to save my le so that I am here for my kids.rsquoldquoRight now, I just feel like somebody has put a plastic bag over my head and is slowly tightening it and I cannot breathe.ldquoIt is the last thing you think about at night and the first thing you think about in the morning.ldquoYou automatically think you would have it removed and have chemotherapy but to be told that you cannot, that they will not go in and do anythinghellipThe Tranent mum had been referred to hospital for brain and spinal MRIs after it was thought she had MS .However, the scans showed it was worse than first thought, with Trudie, who is mum to Joshand Naomi , who attend Ross High School, Zak , who will be starting at Knox Academy Meadowpark, and eight-year-old Archie, who attends Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, in Tranent, saying she ldquofelt numb after being told she had an inoperable brain tumour.A biopsy and chemotherapy have both been ruled out by experts due to the location of the tumour.She said: ldquoThey donrsquot know how aggressive it is because they cannot do the biopsy.ldquoThey were throwing everything at me ndash there are  types of brain cancer. They donrsquot know how quick it is going to grow.ldquoIrsquove been told I will start to have epileptic fits, I will lose my mobility and even simple things like swallowing I will be unable to do.With options on the NHS limited, Trudie and her husband Dave, who tied the knot  months ago, are looking at the possibility of travelling to America or other countries for treatment.Trudie, who has lived in Tranent for about eight years after previously living in Musselburgh, where she attended the townrsquos secondary school, said a hospital in America could use a needle ldquoas thin as a hair to take a biopsy, while the possibility of operating on the tumour had not been ruled out.Unfortunately, that would mean raising thousands of pounds to cover expensive medical bills.Friends and family rallied round for the online appeal, with more than pound, already raised.Trudie, , encouraged people to get in touch with raffle prizes for a future fundraiser and said: ldquoPeople can surprise you.ldquoIt is not always the people you are closest to that reach out but people I have not spoken to for a while that reach out to you."There are strangers I have never met that are donating money to somebody that they donrsquot know, especially just now because of lockdown.ldquoEverybody has been affected by this financially one way or another and I certainly did not expect to get over pound,.Dave, who works as a residential childcare worker in Ormiston, described the news as ldquodevastating.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is hard to put it into words."She is so young, has so much to give and has so much to look forward to for this to potentially take her away, knowing potentially that something can be done ndash there are no words.To support Trudie, go to gofundme f treatment-for-trudie

title: plans-car-park-elcho-green-shelved
story: Councillors and council officials have this week been inundated with angry comments from disbelieving residents, protesting against cherished recreational area Elcho Green, at North Berwickrsquos West Bay, being utilised for an -space long-stay car park.The local authority said in a statement last Tuesday that, as part of ious measures inNorth Berwick to provide extra space for physical distancing to protect public health and suppress a resurgence of Covid-, including widening pavements at the east end of High Street, it would be ldquoconverting part of Elcho Green to a temporary car park to support access to the High Street area.It stated that ldquofollowing a meeting with local traders, North Berwick CommunityCouncil and North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, agreement has been reached to introduce a number of temporary measures in the town ndash but both the community council and area partnership told the Courier they had not given backing to the Elcho Green changes.The councilrsquos own timetable had Elcho Green car park opening last Friday .An online petition, West Bay not Parking Bay, to ldquoprotect stunning and iconic West Bay in North Berwick, was launched by resident Sarah Russell and had attracted more than , signatures in less than a week.It said: ldquoEast Lothian Council have announced plans to turn Elcho Green into a longstay car park.ldquoWhilst the council state that this is a temporary measure to comply with their Covid Spaces for People initiative, it is greatly feared that this will, in fact, lead to a permanent car park in the most iconic seafront location in East Lothian."North Berwick residents and visitors alike will be robbed of the very essence of this beautul recreational space that personies this famous conservation area seafront.ldquoTemporary or otherwise, Elcho Green is not the correct location for any car parking and we would urge you to help us stop this environmental catastrophe.Among those supporting the campaign was world-famous golfer and North Berwick resident Catriona Matthew, captain of Europersquos winning Solheim Cup team.The Courier has been swamped with letters and emails against the plans .The scheme was described as ldquoindefensible and ldquoundemocratic vandalism by some residents, while many asked why there had not been specic consultation on the plan and highlighted that the land had been gted to the town by the late Sir Hew Hamilton-Dalrymple for recreational use in .On Monday, East Lothian Council released a statement that it was placing the ldquoElcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult.It is the second time in a month that the councilrsquos plans to transform town centres have hit the buffers.Earlier in July, proposals to suspend parking in town centres were put ldquoon hold after traders and residents in Haddington reacted with anger as cones and parking suspension signs were put up overnight, sparking widespread concern.In Mondayrsquos statement, Councillor Norman Hampshire , environment spokesperson, said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has successfully implemented a number of physical distancing measures on North Berwick High Street to support the need for safe access to the town centre and economic recovery.ldquoA further support for Spaces for People was a proposal to utilise a small part of Elcho Green in North Berwick as a temporary car park.ldquoThe benefit of this would have been a reduction in the number of vehicles circling and queuing for parking spaces, enhanced safety for pedestrians and cyclists within the town centre, and improved air quality.ldquoEast Lothian Council is a listening authority and we are aware of the ious perspectives being raised within the North Berwick community.ldquoAs such, we intend to place the Elcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult."This delay will also enable us to monitor the impact of increased traffic as a result of visitors and to assess the effectiveness of measures introduced.Councillor Stuart Currie, SNP Group leader, said that recent u-turns were down to a ldquolack of political leadership within the Labour administration.He said he received more than  emails objecting to the Elcho Green plans.He called for a report on the Spaces for People plans, and in particular parking proposals in North Berwick, to be put before a meeting of elected council group leaders in two weeksrsquo time for approval.Under emergency Covid- procedures, normal council business is currently suspended and decisions are taken at monthly meetings of the group leaders and council chief executive.He said: ldquoThe decision must be approved by councillors at the leadersrsquo group meeting and it should be open and transparent and open to the press.Mr Hampshire accused Mr Currie of ldquoplaying politics in ldquoan emergency situation.ldquoWe have allowed him to take part in the meetings with officers at every point during the discussions, said Mr Hampshire.ldquoI have got to say the Conservative Group have been fully behind what we are doing."For the SNP to try to play politics in a situation where their own Government is instructing local authorities to create spaces in town centres is unbelievable.Conservative councillor Craig Hoy called on the administration to ldquotake notice of the recent problems caused by parking proposals.He said the Scottish Government had failed to give councils enough time to push through emergency Covid measures in town centres.Councillor Hoy said: "Scottish Councils are operating under huge pressure with limited resources, but that does not remove the need for them to consult fully and communicate clearly on big issues which impact our communities."I hope East Lothian Council and the Labour administration will take notice of the recent problems in North Berwick and fully engage with stakeholders."Hilary Smith, chair of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, stressed that the area partnership had not attended any meeting regarding Covid- plans for the town or given its approval to the plans.North Berwick Community Council said it had not discussed Elcho Green prior to its meeting on Tuesday.East Lothian Council received pound.million from Scottish Government funding for Spaces for People projects to make social distancing easier in town centres and encourage people toto them safely.The council launched a consultation in May, asking people for their county-wide views.It attracted , contributions and more than  comments, including more than  from the North Berwick area.But North Berwick residents have not been asked their specic views on Elcho Green car parking.The council said it had given consideration to parking availability at a number of sites in North Berwick.In response to questions from the Courier, the council said: ldquoThe high school and sports centre are both due to re-open in coming weeks so were unsuitable to use.ldquoAn area of Elcho Green is considered suitable to take traffic arriving from the west to park for people visiting the town to intercept the flow of traffic and stop vehicles circulating through the town unnecessarily searching for parking spaces and generating additional traffic pollution.ldquoIt also seemed reasonable considering the area of land is used annually for Fringe by the Sea events."A maximum of  places had been identied for use as a potential temporary car park which is not part of the Spaces for People grant but provided as part of the programme.

title: world-famous-singer-pops-east-lothian-cafe
story: Sam visited JoLi, based in The Old Reading Rooms on Longniddryrsquos Main Street.Sam is said to have bought a coffee and some gts, with those at the cafe saying that the Grammy Award-winner stopped off on their travels to North Berwick.Staff at JoLi were ldquoa little bit starstruck when the singer popped by, saying the visit was ldquosomething you do not expect.They described the singer as a ldquolovely guy.A post sharing the news of the visit on social media has attracted a lot of attention from starstruck fans, with one fellow diner saying that she was in having lunch at the time and did not recognise the star.Sam, , is a British singer-songwriter who emerged onto the music scene in .Since then the musician, who delayed the release of their third album, has had several number one and top  hits in both the UK and US, and in  released Writingrsquos on the Wall, the theme song for the James Bond film Spectre.As well as Grammy Awards, Sam has won Brit Awards, Billboard Music Awards, American Music Awards, a Golden Globe and an Academy Award.It is believed Sam is on holiday in East Lothian with his family.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-reopens-doors-today
story: The coronavirus pandemic forced the venue to close in mid-March but now preparations have been made and put in place for its reopening.The Seabird Centre, which is an independent charity, will open Thursday-Sunday, am-pm, in what it describes as a ldquohugely positive step.It will then close Monday-Wednesday to allow staff to review the visitor experience over the temporary opening time and make improvements where needed.Staff at the centre are ldquoreally excited to welcome people back and hope to be back to a daily am-pm opening from next Thursday .Several new processes are in place to help manage numbers and ensure everyone can visit safely, including a new booking system.The number of people allowed in at any one time will be signicantly reduced to about  per cent of normal capacity to allow for physical distancing.Because of this reduction, the Seabird Centre will only be able to earn a fraction of its usual income, meaning its future in the months ahead ldquoremains challenging.Having to suddenly close its doors in March due to Covid- had a ldquodevastating effect on the Seabird Centrersquos finances as it was forced to close at the beginning of the summer tourism season, something it relies on.In May it launched its first-ever urgent public appeal, which saw it aim to raise pound, and save it from permanent closure. This, alongside emergency funding from a number of sources, has allowed the centre to reopen its doors once again and welcome back visitors.Susan Davies, the centrersquos CEO, said: ldquoIt is with great relief that we have been able to navigate a course through this turbulent financial period and are now able to welcome visitors back to our centre.Full details on the new systems, safety procedures and opening dates and times in place can be found at seabird.orgThe Seabird Centrersquos public appeal ends next Friday .To donate, visit justgiving campaign SeabirdSOS
