story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityOn Tuesday ldquoscrew in bollards replaced temporary cones and steel barriers along Glebe Street, Windsor Road and where in the town to stop cars from parking in bays, allowing for pedestrians to socially distance.A petition which was started on Thursday calling on the Vale council to reconsider the parking measures has attracted more than  signatures online.Butcher Marcus Lush of David Lush Butchers on Glebe Street, explained his frustration when he said a representative of Vale council arrived on Wednesday morning to ldquoglue down the bollards.Marcus Lush said Glebe Street on Saturday was very quiet. He says he would usually have queues around the corner.ldquoThey put bollards in my loading bay on Tuesday morning, he said, ldquoI was annoyed but I was informed they could be removed, as they were screwed in.ldquoKnowing this, I did screw them out to allow for my morning deliveries, of which I have many and the drivers need to park close to the shop to carry the produce on their shoulders.ldquoI was shocked on Wednesday morning when someone from the council turned up to stick the bollards to the floor so I could no longer remove them.ldquoIt means my delivery drivers are having to carry huge amounts of produce on their back for well over an hour, when it would usually take about  minutes.ldquoItrsquos unsustainable and inhumane. It also means our business isnrsquot efficient.The Vale council says the measures were implemented based on government guidance and discussion with representatives of tradersrsquo groups in Penarth, as well as the town council.Shoppers have said they have been going where due to the restrictions, and it is deterring them for shopping locally, while others have said it could be a good thing for the town.Cllr Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Education and Regeneration, said: ldquoThe safety of shoppers visiting town centres in the Vale is our number one priority and so measures designed to promote social distancing and protect people have been introduced in these locations.ldquoThis has involved removing some parking bays in order to create more safe space for pedestrians at pinch points in the towns.ldquoThe new more stream-lined fixed bollards are less overpowering in the street scene and after the most recent review the number of parking bays affected has been reduced to specic pinch-points.ldquoWe continue to meet with town councils and business representatives and will regularly review the measures to ensure they reflect the changing situation in our shopping centres. In this way we hope to support local businesses while encouraging shoppers towith confidence to town centres.Mr Lush says to add salt to the wound, since parking restrictions have been put in place, he has seen a noticeable decrease in sales, and this Saturday was one of the quietest he has seen.       ,params: .pushldquoWersquove tried our best through lockdown to remain open and serve the town story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityCross Common bridge in Dinas Powys was closed off to drivers in February , after a new access road was built and the safety of the old bridge was questioned.The council abandoned the bridge and put up red and white plastic barriers to stop traffic driving over it.In August last year, the council promised to begin the work to remove the bridge that October mdash after delays in finding a specialist contractor.Now, with the bridge still there a year later, Plaid Cymru community councillors are demanding the council act, and either remove the bridge or turn it into a footpath and clear the debris and plastic barriers.Cllr Chris Franks said: ldquoFor three years, the Vale has said this bridge has got to go. If theyrsquore going to do it, theyrsquove got to get on with it. These ugly barriers are so frustrating, and thousands of people see it.ldquoThey did some excavations and just left the spoil heap. Itrsquos a vast improvement now, but even cleaned up itrsquos still a mess.Jean Webber, who lives nearby on Llwyn Derwen, said she has witnessed a lot of fly-tippers dumping rubbish at the bridge, like fridges, freezers and buildersrsquo rubbish. She said: ldquoI think this end of Dinas has been forgotten. [The council] seems to concentrate on the other end.ldquoI walk past here every day. It wouldnrsquot be so badthey just walled it off. I never complain, but this is just appalling.The council has now promised work will begin to remove the bridge next month, and blamed coronavirus for the most recent delay. The new timetable is to finish the job by this October.A Vale of Glamorgan council spokesperson said: ldquoUnfortunately, the contractor originally appointed to remove the bridge withdrew from the project after agreement couldnrsquot be reached on a claim for additional costs due to the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoThat meant a new contractor had to be found, a process that added to the delay caused by the pandemic itself, which for a period prevented work of this type being carried out.ldquoThe council has now successfully appointed a new contractor and received an indication that work is expected to start in mid-August. It is anticipated the work will be completed by the end of October.But both Cllr Franks and Ms Webber raised doubts about the new timetable. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. They also said a trial period will not take place in August and September.Ideas, revealed by the town council in an online questionnaire on Friday, includes a pedestrianised ldquosafe space on Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout, including the bottom of Lower Glebe Street.Other plans for Windsor Road could include ldquoshared spaces between pedestrians and traffic during set times, while another included only allowing service traffic ndash such as delivery vehicles ndash to access Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street.One of the major points for discussion is around proposals for a one-way traffic system incorporating Albert Road, Stanwell Road, Hickman Road, Arcot Street,Glebe Street and Ludlow Lane.The grey area marks the safe space pedestrianised proposal.The town council say the one-way system would enable more chevron parking on Plassey Street, Albert Road and Stanwell Road.Ceri McCann, Rachel Came and Karen Hatton at Andrearsquos Flower Boutique on Glebe Street, think the town will sufferpedestrianisation plans go ahead.: Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" alt"Penarth Times: : Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" class"editor-image": Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe StreetldquoPenarth isnrsquot the type of place you come to and spend a day, itrsquos a place people come and park up and quickly do some shopping, they said. ldquoBusinesses are already feeling the impact of lower footfall due to the social distancing parking trials, and to add this to the mix is poor timing.The plans also include additional bus stops, including one right outside Joan Painesrsquo funeral directors.The new ideas are designed to bring an additional  spaces to the town centre, but this is likely to affect residentsShe says buses stopping outside her shop every half an hour - combined with the one-way system - would be likely to cause too much congestion.ldquoMy main concern is the congestion and the impact that will have on my customers, she said. ldquoIt is not nice to have so much noise, fumes, and congestion outside when yoursquore trying to sort out a funeral.Joan and Tony Paines have made a blown up version of the main town area, so people can better understand the ideas.Ms Paines suggested a bus terminal at Station Approach, and said she thinks a one-way system around the town will also cause heavy traffic on smaller roads such as Railway Terrace, Grove Terrace and Woodland Place.Resident and member of Friendsof the Earth Barry andVale Max Wallis said he is in support of partial pedestrianisation, but questioned the one-way system idea.Mr Wallis said that a one-way system would ldquoworsen traffic and add to town centre pollution, adding: ldquoCovid- will force new thinking. People see the benefits of more walking and cycling. Some shops and businesses will close, with more online shopping. The town centre must become more a meeting and activity place access by bus or bike is more attractive withthe reduced traffic.       ,params: .pushMax WallisStrategic consultant John Jackson, who lives in Penarth, is in favour of partial pedestrianisation of Windsor Road on a trial basis.ldquoThis system works abroad, and works abroad in places where the weather isnrsquot always nice, he said. ldquoI think Penarth needs to be a more attractive environment post lockdown, and that would involve some sort of pedestrianisation.ldquoI think the idea to close off Windsor Road from Lower Glebe Street to the roundabout isnrsquot a bad one, and could instil some confidence for future changes.ldquoWhat I would question is whether the timing is right so soon after businesses have reopened.Five hundred people have responded to the town council survey so far.Cllr Nigel Humphrey - for St Augustines - said: ldquoPeople have been responding to the survey asit is a done deal, when in fact it is intended as part of a constructive dialogue about the future of our town centre."Gideon Calder of Gwyrddio Penarth Greeningsaid: ldquoFrom conversations with people, some are assuming that the current arrangement in the town centre ndash the bollards and one-way system ndash is the same thing as these alternative ideas about creating safer space."In fact these plans are quite dferent. Theyrsquore intended as a solutionto many of the problems which people are identying with things as they are.In a questionnaire circulated to traders by Penarth Business Group which waspassed onto the town council, of the  responders , . per cent said they against partof Windsor Road becoming a traffic free zone. . per cent said they were in favour of a one-way system being introduced to the town centre. . per cent said they were in favour of using wider roads for chevron parking.If you would like to find out more about the proposals visithttps:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk news penarth-post-covid-your-views-on-our-town-centre .If you would like to make your views known but cannot access the survey online, you can call Penarth Town Council on   Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Northern Irish sheddie Trevor Carswell, , is through to the finals of the  Cuprinol Shed Of The YearHe said: “It was built using salvaged items and most of the objects inside are keepsake memoirs collected over the years.
